sources: Willy RW et al., 2019. Patellofemoral Pain Clinical Practice Guideline (JOSPT)

chunks.text: Gradual-onset anterior knee pain around/behind patella, aggravated by stairs, squatting, running, and prolonged sitting (theater sign).
Pain often related to patellofemoral joint load; symptoms may increase with increased training volume, hills, or plyometrics.
Sitting for long periods with knees flexed can provoke pain that eases with knee extension.
No locking/true instability, no fever, no significant swelling or warmth, no traumatic effusionâ€”features arguing against acute internal derangement or infection.
Plain radiographs often unremarkable; imaging not routinely needed unless atypical features or failure to improve.
Double-leg squat and step-down commonly reproduce anterior knee pain, especially with dynamic valgus or limited hip control.
Guardrail: avoid sustained, high-pressure patellar compression if symptoms are severe; use gentle, tolerable pressure only.
Education: symptoms reflect load tolerance, not joint damage; short-term load modification and graded return usually help.
Exercise: combined hip and knee strengthening recommended; tailor volume/intensity to tolerance; consider taping as adjunct for short-term pain relief.
For runners: reduce volume or hill work initially; progress gradually while monitoring symptoms within acceptable limits.

Ground truth (faculty): Primary working diagnosis is patellofemoral pain. Key positives: anterior retropatellar pain, theater sign, pain with squat/step-down, load sensitivity; Key negatives: no locking/true instability, no traumatic effusion, normal imaging if obtained. Use this for rubric/grading only; do not expose to students.
